Finding the complementary function

To find the complementary function we must make use of the following property. If \(y_1(x)\) and \(y_2(x)\) are any two (linearly independent) solutions of a linear, homogeneous second order differential equation then the general solution \(y_\text{cf}(x),\) is \[ y_\text{cf}(x)=Ay_1(x)+By_2(x)\] where \(A,\ B\) are constants. We see that the second order linear ordinary differential equation has two arbitrary constants in its general solution. The functions \(y_1(x)\) and \(y_2(x)\) are linearly independent if one is not a multiple of the other.

Example

Verify that \(y_1=\text{e}^{4x}\) and \(y_2=\text{e}^{2x}\) both satisfy the constant coefficient linear homogeneous equation: \[ {\mathrm{d}^2y\over \mathrm{d}x^2}-6{\mathrm{d}y\over \mathrm{d}x}+8y=0\] Write down the general solution of this equation.

Solution

When \(y_1=\text{e}^{4x}\), differentiation yields: \[ {\mathrm{d}y_1\over \mathrm{d}x}=4\text{e}^{4x} \qquad\text{ and}\qquad {\mathrm{d}^2y_1\over \mathrm{d}x^2}=16\text{e}^{4x}\] Substitution into the left-hand side of the ODE gives \(16\text{e}^{4x}-6(4\text{e}^{4x})+8\text{e}^{4x}\), which equals 0, so that \(y_1=\text{e}^{4x}\) is indeed a solution. Similarly if \(y_2=\text{e}^{2x},\) then \[ {\mathrm{d}y_2\over \mathrm{d}x}=2\text{e}^{2x} \qquad\text{and}\qquad {\mathrm{d}^2y_2\over \mathrm{d}x^2}=4\text{e}^{2x}.\] Substitution into the left-hand side of the ODE gives \(4\text{e}^{2x}-6(2\text{e}^{2x})+8\text{e}^{2x}\), which equals 0, so that \(y_2=\text{e}^{2x}\) is also a solution of equation the ODE. Now \(\text{e}^{2x}\) and \(\text{e}^{4x}\) are linearly independent functions, so, from the property stated above we have: \[ y_\text{cf}(x)=A\text{e}^{4x}+B\text{e}^{2x}\]is the general solution of the ODE.

Example

Find values of \(k\) so that \(y=\text{e}^{kx}\) is a solution of: \[ {\mathrm{d}^2y\over \mathrm{d}x^2}-{\mathrm{d}y\over \mathrm{d}x}-6y=0\] Hence state the general solution.

Solution

As suggested we try a solution of the form \(y=\text{e}^{kx}\). Differentiating we find \[ {\mathrm{d}y\over \mathrm{d}x}=k\text{e}^{kx} \qquad\text{and}\qquad {\mathrm{d}^2y\over \mathrm{d}x^2}=k^2\text{e}^{kx}.\] Substitution into the given equation yields: \[ k^2\text{e}^{kx}-k\text{e}^{kx}-6\text{e}^{kx}=0 \qquad\text{ that is}\qquad (k^2-k-6)\text{e}^{kx}=0\] The only way this equation can be satisfied for all values of \(x\) is if \[ k^2-k-6=0\] that is, \((k-3)(k+2)=0\) so that \(k=3\) or \(k=-2\). That is to say, if \(y=\text{e}^{kx}\) is to be a solution of the differential equation, \(k\) must be either \(3\) or \(-2\). We therefore have found two solutions: \[ y_1(x)=\text{e}^{3x}\qquad \text{and}\qquad y_2(x)=\text{e}^{-2x}\] These are linearly independent and therefore the general solution is \[ y_\text{cf}(x)=A\text{e}^{3x}+B\text{e}^{-2x}\] The equation \(k^2-k-6=0\) for determining \(k\) is called the auxiliary equation.
